questions.question: Which of the following is characteristic of the animal cell?
options: Possession of a cellulose cell wall
questions.explanation: Animal cells have few, scattered small vacuoles. The presence of chromosomes is common to all cells.

questions.question: All living organisms
questions.explanation: All living organisms feed to obtain energy and build body structures.

questions.question: The vacuole of a plant cell is
options: smaller than that of an animal cell
questions.explanation: The membrane-bound vacuole contains cell sap; the membrane is called a tonoplast.

questions.question: The part of the cell solely responsible for respiration is the
questions.explanation: Mitochondria are the sites of energy release in aerobic respiration and are called the 'powerhouse' of the cell.

questions.question: Which of these combinations is common to plant and animal cells?
options: Centriole, middle lamella, Golgi bodies, mitochondrion
Cytoplasm, sap vacuole, starch grains, leucoplasts
Nucleus, nucleolus, cellulose cell wall, endoplasmic reticulum
Cytoplasm, centriole, cellulose cell wall, nucleolus
questions.explanation: These organelles (plasma membrane, chromosomes, mitochondria, lysosomes) are common to both plant and animal cells. Plant cells have a cellulose wall, chloroplasts, no centrioles, and one large vacuole; animal cells have no cell wall, no chloroplasts, centrioles, and few scattered vacuoles.

questions.question: Where is energy produced in a cell?
questions.explanation: Mitochondria are known as the 'powerhouses of the cell' because they produce energy in the form of ATP through cellular respiration.

questions.question: Which of the following cell constituents is NOT common to both plants and animals?
questions.explanation: Chloroplasts are found only in plant cells (and some algae) for photosynthesis and are not present in animal cells.

questions.question: A group of similar cells performing the same function is
questions.explanation: A tissue is a collection of similar cells that work together to perform a specific function.

questions.question: The function of endoplasmic reticulum is
options: digestion and destruction of foreign bodies
questions.explanation: The primary function of the endoplasmic reticulum is the intracellular transport of materials. The rough ER is also involved in protein synthesis.

questions.question: The oxidative part of the respiration process takes place in the
questions.explanation: The oxidative processes (Krebs cycle and electron transport chain) occur in the mitochondria. Glycolysis (non-oxidative) occurs in the cytoplasm.

questions.question: Which of the following organelles are likely to be present in cells that are actively respiring and photosynthesizing?
questions.explanation: Mitochondria are for respiration, and chloroplasts are for photosynthesis.

questions.question: The structure labelled I is the
questions.explanation: Label I is identified as the mitochondrion.

questions.question: Protein is synthesized in the part labelled
questions.explanation: Ribosomes (label III) are the site of protein synthesis.

questions.question: The nucleus is considered the control organelle of a cell because it
options: is bounded by the nuclear membrane
is located at the centre of the cell
questions.explanation: The nucleus contains DNA (genetic material) which controls all cellular activities.

questions.question: The structure that is most commonly identified in all living cells under the light microscope is the
questions.explanation: The nucleus is the most easily stained and prominent structure under a light microscope.

questions.question: Which of the following is an organ?
questions.explanation: The liver is an organ. A guard cell is a cell, xylem bundle is a tissue, and blood is a tissue (fluid connective tissue).

questions.question: In plant cells, the chloroplasts are located
questions.explanation: Cell organelles, including chloroplasts, are suspended within the cytoplasm.

questions.question: Which of the following organisms does not exist as a single free living cell?
questions.explanation: Volvox is a colonial organism, not a single free-living cell. The others are unicellular.

questions.question: An Amoeba and an unlaid chicken egg are
questions.explanation: Both are examples of single cells. An unlaid egg is a single cell (ovum).

questions.question: The structures found only in plant cells are
questions.explanation: The cell wall (cellulose) and chloroplasts are unique to plant cells.

questions.question: The endoplasmic reticulum is represented by the part labelled
questions.explanation: Label II represents the endoplasmic reticulum.

questions.question: The part labelled II is responsible for
questions.explanation: Based on the diagram key, label II (ER) is associated with respiration in this specific context.

questions.question: The rods in the retina of the eye are examples of
questions.explanation: Rods are specialized photoreceptor cells.

questions.question: The organelle common to both plant and animal cell is the
questions.explanation: The plasmalemma (cell membrane) is present in both. Centrioles are animal-specific, cell wall and chloroplasts are plant-specific.

questions.question: Which of the following is likely to have a higher concentration of mitochondria?
questions.explanation: Sperm cells require a lot of energy (ATP) for movement, so they contain many mitochondria.

questions.question: The role of the Golgi complex in a eukaryotic cell is to
options: Conduct ions in and out of the cell
transport genetic material out of the cell
transport organic material in and out of the cell
questions.explanation: The Golgi complex processes, packages, and transports organic materials (proteins, lipids) via vesicles.

questions.question: The organelle responsible for heredity is
questions.explanation: The nucleus (label III) contains the DNA responsible for heredity.

questions.question: The part labelled I is the
questions.explanation: Label I is the cell membrane (plasmalemma).

questions.question: A characteristic that can possibly be shared by both living and nonliving organisms is
questions.explanation: Non-living things (e.g., crystals) can increase in size, but they do not grow through metabolic processes like living organisms.

questions.question: The cell of an onion bulb can be differentiated from a cheek cell by the presence of
questions.explanation: Onion cells (plant) have a cell wall, while cheek cells (animal) do not.

questions.question: What is the level of organization of an onion bulb?
questions.explanation: An onion bulb is an organ, composed of different tissues (e.g., storage tissue, protective scale leaves).

questions.question: A characteristic exhibited by all living organisms is
options: the ability to move from one place to another
the ability to remove unwanted substances
questions.explanation: All living organisms excrete waste products (excretion). Not all reproduce sexually, respire aerobically, or exhibit locomotion.

questions.question: In a cell, the genes are carried by
questions.explanation: Genes are located on the chromatin threads (DNA + proteins) within the nucleus.

questions.question: Which of the following characterizes a mature plant cell?
options: The nucleus is pushed to the centre of the cell
The cell wall is made up of cellulose
The nucleus is small and irregular in shape
The cytoplasm fills up the entire cell space
questions.explanation: A key characteristic of plant cells is a rigid cell wall made primarily of cellulose.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a function of the nucleus of a cell?
options: It translates genetic information for the manufacture of proteins
it stores and carries hereditary information
it is a reservoir of energy for the cell
it controls the life processes of the cell
questions.explanation: The nucleus controls cell activities via genetic information but does not store energy; mitochondria perform that function.

questions.question: The organelle responsible for heredity is labelled
questions.explanation: The nucleus (label III) contains the hereditary material (DNA).

questions.question: The part labelled IV is the
questions.explanation: Label IV is identified as the mitochondrion.

questions.question: The organelles present in cells that are actively respiring and photosynthesizing are
questions.explanation: Mitochondria are for respiration, and chloroplasts are for photosynthesis.

questions.question: The lowest level of organization in living organisms is
questions.explanation: The cell is the basic unit of life and the lowest level of organization.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most complex according to their cellular level of organization?
questions.explanation: The heart is an organ (organ level). Hair is primarily tissue level. Euglena is unicellular. Hydra has tissue-level organization.

questions.question: Which of the following organisms is multicellular?
questions.explanation: Spirogyra is a multicellular filamentous alga. The others are unicellular protists.

questions.question: The organelles present in cells that are actively respiring and photosynthesizing are
questions.explanation: Mitochondria are for respiration, and chloroplasts are for photosynthesis.

internal-structure-of-plants-animals.name: Internal structure of plants and animals

factors-affecting-the-distribution-of-or.name: Factors afffecting the distribution of organisms

Symbiotic-interactions-of-plants-and-ani.name: Symbiotic interactions of plants and animals
